children.subject: Lmao you can also post this on the Math 101 Piazza

history.content:
To show something is conditionally convergent, you need only show that the given series is convergent but not absolutely convergent. You can use the alternating series test for this. See here

You have $$\Sigma (-1)^n a_n$$. To show that this is convergent, just check if $$a_n$$ here is monotonically decreasing and $$lim_{n \to \infty} a_n = 0$$

To check for absolute convergence, you should take $$\Sigma |(-1)^n a_n|$$ and show that it diverges.

To show something is conditionally convergent, you need only show that the given series is convergent but not absolutely convergent. You can use the alternating series test for this. See here

You have $$\Sigma (-1)^n a_n$$. To show that this is convergent, just check if $$a_n$$ here is monotonically decreasing and $$lim_{n \to \infty} a_n = 0$$

To check for absolute convergence, you should take $$\Sigma |(-1)^n a_n|$$ and show that it diverges. a_n here is just the terms in the parantheses apart from (-1)^n

To show something is conditionally convergent, you need only show that the given series is convergent but not absolutely convergent. You can use the alternating series test for this. See here

You have $$\Sigma (-1)^n a_n$$. To show that this is convergent, just check if $$a_n$$ here is monotonically decreasing and $$lim_{n \to \infty} a_n = 0$$

To check for absolute convergence, you should take \Sigma_{n=1}_{\infty} |(-1)^n a_n| and show that it diverges. a_n here is just the terms in the parantheses apart from (-1)^n

To show something is conditionally convergent, you need only show that the given series is convergent but not absolutely convergent. You can use the alternating series test for this. See here

You have \Sigma_{n=1}_{\infty} (-1)^n a_n. To show that this is convergent, just check if $$a_n$$ here is monotonically decreasing and $$lim_{n \to \infty} a_n = 0$$

To check for absolute convergence, you should take \Sigma_{n=1}_{\infty} |(-1)^n a_n| and show that it diverges. a_n here is just the terms in the parantheses apart from (-1)^n

To show something is conditionally convergent, you need only show that the given series is convergent but not absolutely convergent. You can use the alternating series test for this. See here

You have $$\Sigma_{n=1}_{\infty} (-1)^n a_n$$. To show that this is convergent, just check if $$a_n$$ here is monotonically decreasing and $$lim_{n \to \infty} a_n = 0$$

To check for absolute convergence, you should take $$\Sigma_{n=1}_{\infty} |(-1)^n a_n|$$ and show that it diverges.

Let me know if it is inappropriate to post math questions on piazza and I will delete the post; I just really couldn't figure out this one and I don't know where to get help...

This series is said to be conditionally convergent, but I cannot prove it. Does anyone have any idea how to do it? Thanks!
history.subject: Conditional convergence of a series
